Here,
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$m_{ij}(t)$$\end{document}
m
ij
( t )
represents the volume of individuals moving from city i to city j at time t. Here, we assume the population of city j is
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$P_j$$\end{document}
P j
. Then, the number of infected individuals moving from city i to city j is

ji
. Then, the number of infected individuals moving out of city j is

Thus, the dynamic change of the number of infected cases in city j at time t is given by
4
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned}\Delta I_j(t) &=\kappa _jE_i(t)-\gamma _j I_j(t) \\&\quad +{k_I} \left( \sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{I_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\right. \\&\quad \left. -\frac{I_j(t)\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)}\right) , \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

. Moreover, if city i has a population of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$P_i$$\end{document}
P i
and the eventual percentage of infection is
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\delta _i$$\end{document}

, then
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$N_i^s= \delta _i P_i$$\end{document}
N i s
=
δ i
P i
. Thus, we have
5
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} N_i^s(t) = S_i(t)+E_i(t)+I_i(t)+R_i(t), \end{aligned}$$\end{document}
N i s
( t )
=
S i
( t )

E i
( t )

I i

R i
( t )
,
where
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$N_i^s$$\end{document}
N i s
is the eventual number of infections. Similarly, the dynamic changes of infected, susceptible, recovered individuals, and the population of a city can be obtained. Then, we have the modified SEIR model with consideration of human migration dynamics as follows:
6
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} \Delta I_j(t)&=\kappa _jE_i(t)-\gamma _j I_j(t)\\&\quad +k_I\left( \sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{I_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\right. \\&\quad \left. -\frac{I_j(t)\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)}\right) ,\\ \Delta E_j(t)&=\frac{\beta _j }{N_j^s(t)}I_j(t)S_j(t)\\&\quad +\frac{\alpha _j}{N_j^s(t)} E_j(t)S_j(t) -\kappa _jE_i(t)\\&\quad +\sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{E_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\\&\quad -\frac{E_j(t)*\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)},\\ \Delta S_j(t)&= -\frac{\beta _j }{N_j^s(t)}I_j(t)S_j(t)\\&\quad -\frac{\alpha _j}{N_j^s(t)} E_j(t)S_j(t) +\sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{S_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\\&\quad -\frac{S_j(t)\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)},\\ \Delta R_j(t)&= \gamma _j I_j(t),\\ \Delta P_j(t)&= \sum _{i=1}^Nm_{ij}(t)-\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t),\\ \Delta N_j^s(t)&= k_I\left( \sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{I_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\right. \\&\quad \left. -\frac{I_j(t)\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)}\right) +\sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{E_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\\&\quad -\frac{E_j(t)\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)}\\&\quad +\sum _{i=1}^N{\left( \frac{S_i(t)m_{ij}(t)}{P_i(t)}\right) }\\&\quad -\frac{S_j(t)\sum _{i=1}^N m_{ji}(t)}{P_j(t)}, \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

. The physical meaning of each parameter of model ( 6) is presented in Table 1, while a detailed description of the model is given in [ 1]. Note that we assume the recovered individuals are assumed to stay in the city j.
